bestBHT.bht: Rufus is noted as being one of the elect in the Lord, emphasizing his chosen status as a follower of Christ. His mother and the apostle's connection is described as Rufus's mother by nature and the apostle's mother in a figurative sense, highlighting the tender care exhibited within the community of believers. This affectionate tone suggests a special kindness, while the use of elect underscores Rufus's distinction as a chosen and distinguished Christian. His faith and love for the Lord mark him as an eminent vessel in the eyes of the apostle.

Henry Alford: But the name was very common, the elect,—not to be softened to merely excellent, a sense unknown to our Apostle;—elect, i.e. one of the eleet of the Lord."
and mine the Apostle adds from affectionate regard towards the mother of Rufus: ‘my mother,’ in my reverence and affection for her.
Jowett compares our Lord’s words to St. John, John xix. 27.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: the choice" or "precious one" in the Lord. (See 1 Peter 2:4; 2 John 1:13).
our interest is deepened by what immediately follows about his mother.
Sweet compulsion, if what he thus beheld issued in his voluntarily taking up his own cross!
Albert Barnes: Elect” in the Lord; that is, a chosen follower of Christ.
His mother in a literal sense, and mine in a figurative one.
Religion binds the hearts of all who embrace it tenderly together.
Marvin Vincent: Rufus. Meaning red. Possibly the son of Simon of Cyrene, Mark 14:21. Mark probably wrote in Rome.
And mine. Delicately intimating her maternal care for him.
Philip Schaff: The chosen in the Lord; not merely ‘elect in Christ,’ but a chosen distinguished Christian man.
His mother and mine. 'His mother by nature, mine by maternal kindness.'
The peculiarly affectionate tone suggests some special kindness, in regard to which we can only conjecture.
John Gill: This man was eminent for his faith in Christ.
Rather therefore this is to be understood of his being chosen in Christ to grace and glory and that from all eternity.
The apostle knew this man to be a chosen vessel, not by immediate revelation, or divine inspiration, but by his faith in Christ, and love to him, and by the power of the Gospel on him.
John Wesley: Salute Rufus — Perhaps the same that is mentioned, Mark 15:21.
And his mother and mine — This expression may only denote the tender care which Rufus's mother had taken of him.

bhtAttempts.bht: Rufus, a beloved member of the church, is referred to as one of the elect in the Lord. The word elect holds deep significance, signifying being chosen by the Lord. It is worth noting that Rufus's mother is also mentioned, highlighting the tender care she has shown not only to him but also to the apostle. This speaks to the strong bond formed within the community of believers. The mention of Rufus's mother being his by nature and the apostle's mother in a figurative sense reveals the close relationship and maternal kindness they have shared. The use of elect further emphasizes that Rufus is not merely an excellent individual but a chosen and distinguished follower of Christ. His faith and love for the Lord mark him as an eminent vessel in the eyes of the apostle.

Rufus is noted as being one of the elect in the Lord, emphasizing his chosen status as a follower of Christ. His mother and the apostle's connection is described as Rufus's mother by nature and the apostle's mother in a figurative sense, highlighting the tender care exhibited within the community of believers. This affectionate tone suggests a special kindness, while the use of elect underscores Rufus's distinction as a chosen and distinguished Christian. His faith and love for the Lord mark him as an eminent vessel in the eyes of the apostle.

Rufus, acknowledged as one of the elect in the Lord, holds significance as a chosen follower of Christ. The mention of his mother, both by nature and in a figurative sense, emphasizes the bond within the community of believers. This close connection denotes maternal care and kindness. The choice of elect further highlights Rufus's distinction as a distinguished and chosen Christian. His faith and love for the Lord establish him as a remarkable vessel in the apostle's eyes.

Rufus, recognized as one of the elect in the Lord, symbolizes being chosen by God. The reference to his mother demonstrates the tender care she has shown, both in a literal and figurative sense. This reveals the close bond within the community of believers, as religion unites their hearts affectionately. Rufus is distinguished as a chosen Christian, highlighting his faith in Christ. The apostle's mention of Rufus's mother as his mother and mine signifies the maternal kindness she has extended.

Rufus, one of the elect in the Lord, signifies his chosen status as a follower of Christ. The reference to his mother highlights the care she has shown to both Rufus and the apostle, speaking to the deep bond within the community of believers. Rufus is not simply an excellent individual, but a distinguished and chosen Christian. This affectionate mention suggests a special kindness, reflecting the tight-knit relationships formed among believers. Rufus's faith and love for the Lord mark him as an eminent vessel in the apostle's eyes.
